Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Modeling Ocean Particle Export Flux by Combining Particle Aggregation and Biogeochemical Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
OCE-0645485

An important component of net ecosystem production in the surface ocean sinks to depth where it can be remineralized to carbon dioxide or transit to the bottom. Some of these sinking particles are formed via a number of processes that create rapidly sinking particles that have the potential to transport carbon to the benthos without remineralization. However, currently, very few biogeochemical models explicitly represent the flux of sinking of particles, relying instead on empirical or semi-empirical relationships to distribute material vertically in the water column.
In this integrated research and education CAREER proposal, a researcher from the University of Georgia will focus on the development of numerical models of particle export flux from the surface ocean that can be incorporated into regional and global biogeochemical models. The novel aspect of these models is that they will concentrate on the physical and biological processes (coagulation and fecal pellet production) that transform individual, slowly sinking particles into large, rapidly sinking ones. Naively incorporating coagulation models into these models is computationally prohibitive, so new algorithms and parameterizations will have to be developed that represent the salient features of particle coagulation (e.g., particle settling velocities) and the interaction between particle dynamics, ecosystem dynamics and the physical properties of the water column (such as density). This will be accomplished using physical and biogeochemical models of increasing complexity (such as simple mixed layer models and the JGOFS Regional Test Bed Models), with new parameterizations and algorithms being developed at each stage and influencing the next one.

The educational component of this proposal is integrated with the research component and aims at enhancing quantitative problem solving skills at all levels using real world, oceanographic data sets. High-school and middle-school teachers will be involved in workshops in which they will develop teaching materials for students involving quantitative analysis from publicly available oceanographic data sets. The PI will further develop undergraduate and graduate level courses that will include the construction and analysis of models from large-scale data sets. The work will be of considerable interest to researchers in biogeochemical cycling and global climate change as well as policy makers and the general public by increasing our ability to make more accurate predictions of the effect the ocean has on the planet's climate. The broader impacts also include increased exposure of teachers and students to the development and analysis of models and their use in understanding and solving real-world oceanographic problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Small particulate material in the ocean aggregates to form larger, rapidly settling particles called marine snow. These sinking particles and the processes that transform and degrade them affect the chemistry of the oceans and the transfer of gases between the atmosphere and the upper ocean. Consequently, it is important to have accurate representations of the processes affecting these particles in computer models. This project aimed to assess existing representations, and develop better ones that can be used in global ocean models. The challenge with this is developing models that are complex enough to accurately represent the processes involved while at the same time being simple enough to incorporate into these global models. 

 All mathematical and computer models involve some assumptions and approximations, and we have examined these for a range of models used to represent particles and the processes that transform them. Some of these assumptions concern how many different size classes of particles to consider, others concern how many particles there of different sizes. We have shown that many of these assumptions lead to models that are inaccurate. However, discovering which assumptions generate the inaccuracies and how they do this has allowed us to develop improved algorithms that are far more accurate, but also sufficiently simple to be used in global ocean models. 

 There are strong similarities in the processes affecting detrital particles or organic matter in the ocean and in terrestrial systems. These include the protection of organic matter within aggregates containing minerals such as calcium carbonate and silica, as well as many of the microbial processes operating in soils and in the oceans. Working with terrestrial modelers, we have explored these similarities (and differences) in an attempt to identify gaps in our understanding of of the global carbon cycle and how they might be filled. 

 This results of this project have direct consequences for our ability to accurately predict the response of the ocean to global environmental change. The results of this proposal directly help to improve the accuracy and predictive ability of global biogeochemical and climate models. These models are used to understand the past and present predictions of possible future climates. Being able to accurately model processes affecting particles of organic matter in a manner that is accurate and efficient, allows these processes to be fully represented in global models, improving our understanding of the past and giving us more accurate predictions of the future.   

 Being able to objectively and quantitatively examine the world around us is a skill that is expected of all science students. The fascination people have with the oceans, combined with the abundance of real-time data that is currently available over the internet, provides a perfect vehicle for cultivating these skills in young people. So,  as part of this project we have also worked closely with a group of high school and middle school teachers to help them develop lesson plans and teaching material that combine teaching of quantitative skills in the context of oceanographic data. The materials developed in these workshops have been made publicly available over the internet and all have the tested in the classroom.
